Hi all, 

I am almost done with the basic code and I'll mention some of its=
 features now. I decided to use NetworkX for the genomes, because this modu=
le has lots of useful algorithms and allows any python object to be a node =
and edges can be associated with anything. This makes the evolution of neur=
al networks a tiny part of what's really possible. Any graph can be evolved=
, including undirected graphs and nodes/edges containing discrete one-of-N =
values (integers, lists of python objects, etc). So given that an evaluatio=
n function exists for any kind of graph, you can quickly setup evolution. N=
eural networks are a particular kind of graphs and the package will have bu=
ilt in code necessary to evolve neural networks - the initialization functi=
ons, mutators, and a C++ interface to a class that represents the phenotype=
s. CPPNs support is trivial to make, and given that python functions themse=
lves can be attached to nodes, it's possible to have algorithmic nodes work=
ing with more than one variable and .. well, infinite stuff. OK, I gotta go=
. Wish me luck debugging. Talk to you soon. :) 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogr=
oups.com, Jan van der Lugt <janlugt@...> wrote:
>

>

ke an ambitious and noble plan. Good luck coding, I'm looking

> > Hi people,=

> >
> > For about a month I'll be writing a Python implementation of NEAT,=
 which
> > includes all advances in the recent years, including rtNEAT, pha=
sed
> > searching, leaky integrators, HyperNEAT, HyperNEAT with evolving su=
bstrates,
> > and novelty search. Coevolution code and visualizations will =
be included.
> > Optimized C++ code for running the NNs too. This code will=
 be free and I
> > promise this will be the best NEAT code I can write. No =
bugs, no meaningless
> > NNs, etc.
> >
> > Peter
